item.title: Incentives Drive Outcomes
item.description: It’s well understood that the vast majority of people turn up to work every day wanting to do a great job and be recognised for their efforts in whatever way grants the dopamine hit we all so desire. If this holds true then we should also expect that all workplaces, large or small, operate like a well oiled machine yet we know this isn’t the case. So what’s the happs?

item.title: Swim between the flags
item.description: If you release software with any reasonable cadence, it’s almost inevitable you will end up using a feature flag system of one sort or another. There always comes the time when engineering wants to decouple from the release cycle of the Go To Market (GTM) team and with good reason. The GTM team is slower and more traditional. They want to announce big “drops” and send out the marching band to showcase all the cool new stuff you can do in a process that can take months to orchestrate whereas we prefer to deploy more frequently in small increments.

item.title: Software Ownership Experience
item.description: When I was a teenager I started saving up for my first vehicle and I remember my dad saying the cost of buying it was the cheapest part of the ownership experience. I had not a clue what he meant but as I grew I understood that the cumulative cost of insurance, maintenance, registration, fuel, etc over the time of ownership often dwarfs the cost of purchase.

item.title: In the defence of performance
item.description: Defensive programming is a solid practice to adopt and I generally advocate that we do so but we have to be careful we are still getting the value we expect from the practice.

item.title: Tech Debt Tetris
item.description: Some time ago I was getting an old gameboy up and running again and found myself enjoying a game of Tetris. It occurred to me that this game is not dissimilar to the concept of technical debt.

item.title: Code Crash Investigations
item.description: I’m quite a fan of a Canadian documentary series called Air Crash Investigations. The show re-enacts aviation incidents and the investigations that follow. Admittedly, its a little dark, but its absolutely fascinating. The debris field can be vast and there’s often very little left of the aircraft. None the less, the investigators painstakingly piece together the chain of events and sequences of errors that led to a plane falling out of the sky.

item.title: Complex Solutions To Simple Problems
item.description:
• stages of development of an engineer
    • toddler
      • everything is hard
      • challenge to make things work
    • child
      • things are easier now
      • we kind of understand the world around us
      • we make lots of mess
      • our code works now but is a tighly coupled nightmare
    • teenager
      • its a tough time for most of us
      • look like an adult think like a child
      • we dream up an ever more complex problem domain with non-existet requirements then we solve that problem!
      • massively over-engineered with every edge case covered and re-use of all the things that fails at the first hint of load
      • complex solutions to simple problems
    • adult
      • full comprehension of the world around us (for the most part)
      • ability to simplify and generalise the problems of life
      • break down complex problem domains into simple solutions with pragmatic choices and designs
      • simple solutions to complex problems

item.title: How to Make Your CV Stand Out
item.description: I’ve sometimes taken the opportunity to speak on engineering career panels and a question often asked by new engineers or graduates is ‘How do I make my CV stand out?’ The answers given are often of a similar ilk - write a cover letter, research the company, make sure the employer understands why you’re excited about their particular business. Whilst this is great advice, it may or may not make you stand out. What stands out to me is not the same as what stands out to someone else. Hiring managers are people just like you and I, they have biases, preferences, opinions. There is no one-size-fits-all technique to get your CV into the ‘YES’ pile.

item.title: Who Am I?
item.description: I am a software professional and leader who often finds myself drawing analogies with the non-software world. I like to use these as a tool to both remember and explain my ideas in non-technical terms which I find helps level the playing field when dealing with audiences with mixed levels of technical knowledge.
